ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to read a legal case, what are the legal definitions and tests for agency and agent authority (through a whole bunch of cases), how agency and corporate law interest, economic models of the agency problem.
I learned a lot about agency and fiduciary law through this class. I learned the economic frameworks to engage in those conversations as well.

Learned about agency law, trust law, and the economic analysis of law. Approached them separately at first and then combined them with some game theory and lots of case law. The first part of the course focused on the law, and post-spring break we focused on Economics, with a bit of combining them towards the end.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: this class is SO disorganized. Nice prof, but not enough structure.

The class explores a very interesting and engaging topic. Professor Brooks is so engaging and knowledgeable. However, that is the experience when you are in the classroom. Outside of the classroom, the class is a little disorganized.

Strengths: The depth of Professor Brooks' knowledge, he knows virtually everything about the subject he teaches and is an incredible resources. Weakness: This is somewhat of a strength in difficult times, but a big weakness is lack of structure. There is not a lot of clarity on assignments or expectations and it can make the class feel a little disjointed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: if you're looking for a senior econ seminar w/ a really small workload, take this. But, it's super disorganized and not that interesting unless you're super into contract law

As an Economics student, I found the introduction to law fascinating. I went from having no idea what was going on in the legal cases we were reading to being able to spot the key points being made at the end. It almost feels like learning a new language--each case is in conversation with a wider legal context that you can't get just from reading it. For that reason alone, I would recommend the course!

That said, I think the course runs into some trouble by combining law students and econ undergrads. I found some (but not all) of the economic models less engaging because I had seen them before, and I imagine the same would be true for law students during the law section. Pay attention to whether law or economics will come first on the syllabus, because that will probably take up a majority of the time.
I would definitely recommend this class. Engaging with Professor Brooks is an absolute privilege. However, you must be comfortable with the disorganized schedule and assignments.
Yes! If you are interested in the subject and would enjoy seeing a lot of cases and get an insight into a real law school course, I would recommend taking the course.
